Description: Terracotta stand. A cylindrical stand, tapering from bottom to top. At the top are mouldings, below which is the head of a maenad or young satyr surmounting a vine-scroll that rises from a head of an elderly satyr of Bes-like appearance. The object stands on a low moulded plinth with two rows of dentils. The back is plain. The top and the bottom edges are slightly damaged. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange to red-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close, perhaps same mouldseries: Dunand 1990: no. 973, lower part, dated Roman period (the top part, which is alien, comes from an object close to 3725); Török 1995: no. 305, the lower head identified as Bes; Weber 1914: no. 291, identified as Seilenos. Near: Breccia 1934: no. 440 = Schreiber 1908: 379, fig. 252d; Schürmann 1989: no. 1114, dated first half of second century ad. Bibliog. Vassilika 1995: 203: no. 40.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3273)
